records.full_caption: Figure 1. Illustration of the preparation of PEDOT-PBA as a) a non-imprinted polymer (NIP) film and b) the molecularly imprinted polymer (MIP) film, templated with methyl α-D-glucopyranoside and subsequently washed with 1:1 CH3OH:0.05 m aq. HCl (30 min) and H2O (10 min) for template removal.

Figure 3. Electrochemical measurements of PEDOT-PBA (NIP) and imprinted PEDOT-PBA (MIP) polymer films in PBS electrolyte. The CV curves of the a) NIP and b) MIP before and after interactions with glucose at different concentrations. The scan rate was 50 mV s−1 and the voltage window for forward scan was from −0.2 to 0.4 V versus Ag/AgCl reference electrode. The EIS measurements of c) NIP and d) MIP before and after interactions with glucose at different concentrations. The EIS measurements were conducted at 0 V versus the open-circuit potential.
records.caption: The CV curves of the MIP before and after interactions with glucose at different concentrations.

The EIS measurements of c) NIP and d) MIP before and after interactions with glucose at different concentrations. The EIS measurements were conducted at 0 V versus the open-circuit potential.
records.caption: The EIS measurements of MIP before and after interactions with glucose at different concentrations.

records.full_caption: Figure 4. The OECT biosensor configuration and characteristics. a) The PEDOT-PBA functionalized Au electrode is used as the gate electrode of the OECT with a PEDOT:PSS film in the channel. The channel has a width of 10 μm and length of 100 μm and the gate electrode is 2 mm × 2 mm. The complexation of the PBA unit with glucose molecules occurs at the gate electrode, decreasing the capacitance of the gate electrode, thereby modulating the OECT conductance. The measurement and analyte solution is 1× PBS. b) The output characteristics of the OECT with the NIP electrode as the gate electrode. c,d) The transfer characteristics of the OECT channel gated with the NIP electrode exposed to glucose and fructose solutions of varying concentrations, respectively. The response of the OECT biosensor gated with the NIP electrode (c) or the MIP electrode (d) to glucose and fructose solutions of varying concentrations. e,f) The NR extracted from measurements conducted using 3 gate electrodes. The NR values were extracted at VG = −0.6 and VG = 0.3 V.
records.caption: The output characteristics of the OECT with the NIP electrode as the gate electrode.

records.full_caption: Figure 4. The OECT biosensor configuration and characteristics. a) The PEDOT-PBA functionalized Au electrode is used as the gate electrode of the OECT with a PEDOT:PSS film in the channel. The channel has a width of 10 μm and length of 100 μm and the gate electrode is 2 mm × 2 mm. The complexation of the PBA unit with glucose molecules occurs at the gate electrode, decreasing the capacitance of the gate electrode, thereby modulating the OECT conductance. The measurement and analyte solution is 1× PBS. b) The output characteristics of the OECT with the NIP electrode as the gate electrode. c,d) The transfer characteristics of the OECT channel gated with the NIP electrode exposed to glucose and fructose solutions of varying concentrations, respectively. The response of the OECT biosensor gated with the NIP electrode (c) or the MIP electrode (d) to glucose and fructose solutions of varying concentrations. e,f) The NR extracted from measurements conducted using 3 gate electrodes. The NR values were extracted at VG = −0.6 and VG = 0.3 V.
records.caption: The NR extracted from measurements conducted using 3 gate electrodes.

records.full_caption: Figure 5. QCM-D monitoring of the electrodeposition of PEDOT-PBA films and their glucose sensing performance. The change in a) the frequency (f) and b) the dissipation (D) signals plotted during the polymerization of the NIP film using the 5th, 7th, and 9th overtones. c,d) show the calculated mass changes on the sensors during the electrodeposition of NIP and MIP films. The inset figures in (c) and (d) show the corresponding mass uptake after the electrodeposition step as the glucose concentration is raised in the solution.
records.caption: The change in the frequency (f) signals plotted during the polymerization of the NIP film using the 5th, 7th, and 9th overtones.

records.full_caption: Figure 5. QCM-D monitoring of the electrodeposition of PEDOT-PBA films and their glucose sensing performance. The change in a) the frequency (f) and b) the dissipation (D) signals plotted during the polymerization of the NIP film using the 5th, 7th, and 9th overtones. c,d) show the calculated mass changes on the sensors during the electrodeposition of NIP and MIP films. The inset figures in (c) and (d) show the corresponding mass uptake after the electrodeposition step as the glucose concentration is raised in the solution.
records.caption: The change in the dissipation (D) signals plotted during the polymerization of the NIP film using the 5th, 7th, and 9th overtones.

records.full_caption: Figure 5. QCM-D monitoring of the electrodeposition of PEDOT-PBA films and their glucose sensing performance. The change in a) the frequency (f) and b) the dissipation (D) signals plotted during the polymerization of the NIP film using the 5th, 7th, and 9th overtones. c,d) show the calculated mass changes on the sensors during the electrodeposition of NIP and MIP films. The inset figures in (c) and (d) show the corresponding mass uptake after the electrodeposition step as the glucose concentration is raised in the solution.
records.caption: The calculated mass changes on the sensors during the electrodeposition of MIP films. The inset figure shows the corresponding mass uptake after the electrodeposition step as the glucose concentration is raised in the solution.
